title: Joe Manchin's Inflation Vindication
summary: Prices rise 6.8% in a year, ample reason to shelve the Biden tax and spending blowout.. Forget transitory. Inflation is now persistent, and very high. The Labor Department reported Friday that consumer prices in November rose 6.8% in the last 12 months, the most since 1982. This should be all the warning Democratic doubters need to shelve President Biden's Build Back Better Act that could fuel more inflation.

title: The Category: Who Is Vying to Replace Alex Trebek as 'Jeopardy!' Host
summary: No need to buzz. Just enter your answers and see how well you kept up with the 2021 quiz-show soap opera.. In January, America watched beloved "Jeopardy!" host Alex Trebek deliver his final clue.

title: SpaceX Pilot Sian Proctor Talks About Her Journey-and Returning to Earth
summary: A professor of geology, she was part of the first all-civilian crew to orbit the Earth. Sian Proctor's journey to space began in 1970, when she was born to a father who worked at a NASA tracking station during the Apollo program. She grew up in a home filled with NASA memorabilia and dreamed of becoming a fighter pilot so she could later be an astronaut.

title: How Covid-19 Has Affected Dating, Marriages and Relationships
summary: Resume Subscription. The pandemic has been hard on romantic relationships.

title: Blue Origin Launch With Michael Strahan Caps Record Spaceflight Year
summary: Jeff Bezos's company on Saturday completed its third suborbital trip this year, this time involving four paying customers and two guests. Jeff Bezos's Blue Origin LLC launched six people to the edge of space for a few minutes on Saturday, a trip that rounded out the busiest year for human flights in more than three decades.

title: Merck Falters on Covid-19 Vaccine, Then Makes One for Rival J&J
summary: Resume Subscription. Weeks after Merck & Co. scrapped development of its Covid-19 vaccines in January, one of its senior manufacturing officials began phoning his deputies, telling them their work on a pandemic shot wasn't actually over.

title: How the Pandemic Could Make the Future Brighter for Women in the Workplace
summary: Resume Subscription. The dark cloud that hung over our pandemic year may have a silver lining for women in the workplace.

title: This Supercar Pays Tribute to Ford's Le Mans History
summary: Resume Subscription. Quentin Durward, 67, a neurosurgeon living in Dakota Dunes, S.D., on his 2020 Ford GT Heritage Edition, as told to A.J. Baime.

title: Austria's Curbs on the Unvaccinated Appear to Be Working
summary: Covid-19 measures and a looming general vaccine mandate are persuading more to take the shot as Omicron spreads. Austria, one of the worst-hit countries in Europe's latest Covid-19 surge, has seen infections plummet and vaccination rates soar after imposing a lockdown and saying it would make the shots mandatory next year.

title: Brazil Grapples With Old Nemesis Inflation
summary: Latin America's biggest economy is seen remaining stuck in recession as it confronts double-digit price increases. SÃO PAULO-Inflation is surging in Brazil, forcing a country with one of the highest death rates from Covid-19 to grapple with the economic fallout of the pandemic.

title: The Best-Managed Companies of 2021-and How They Made It to the Top
summary: Microsoft is on top once again in the Drucker Institute's annual Management Top 250 ranking. Among the biggest losers this year: AT&T and ExxonMobil. Technology giants reign as America's best-run companies.

title: What Five Years of Ranking the Best-Managed Companies Reveals
summary: What do the companies with the strongest stocks have in common?. This is the fifth year the Drucker Institute and The Wall Street Journal have compiled the Management Top 250 rankings. With five years of data, we took the opportunity to look back and analyze the performance over time of all the companies eligible for the Top 250.

title: What's New in the Management Top 250 Rankings in 2021
summary: A new metric looks at how well a company's actions match up against goals set by the United Nations. Three of the hottest letters in ESG are SDG.

title: How to Measure How Well a Company Does on Innovation
summary: For the Management Top 250, novelty is seen as a side effect of innovation, not its essence. Innovation is devilishly difficult to measure. So how do we do it?

title: Explore the Top 250 Best-Managed Companies of 2021
summary: Resume Subscription. The Management Top 250 ranking, developed by the Drucker Institute, measures corporate effectiveness by examining performance in five areas: customer satisfaction, employee engagement and development, innovation, social responsibility and financial strength. The ranking is based on an analysis of 34 data inputs provided by 14 third-party sources.

title: Methodology Behind Ranking Management Top 250 Companies
summary: How the Drucker Institute identified the most effectively managed U.S. companies. The Management Top 250 ranking is based on a holistic measure of corporate "effectiveness" that was developed by the Drucker Institute, a part of Claremont Graduate University in Claremont, Calif. "Effectiveness" is defined as "doing the right things well."

title: Over-the-Counter Hearing Aids Are Coming. Here's How to Get Ready.
summary: If you think you have mild or moderate hearing loss, there are ways to prepare for one of the less-expensive hearing aids coming to your drugstore. A hearing-aid disruption is under way, with inexpensive hearing aids heading to drugstores and other retailers sometime next year. But if you're experiencing hearing loss, doctors and hearing experts say it isn't wise to just wait for them to arrive.

title: Biden Puts Union Support at Center of Agenda
summary: President has filled his agenda with pro-labor provisions as Democrats try to keep rank-and-file union members from gravitating toward GOP. President Biden took the stage to promote his $1 trillion infrastructure spending plan after being introduced by a union member, a bus maintenance worker, and quickly made clear who deserved credit for helping get it through Congress, and who would benefit.

title: Inflation Hits Workers Already Worn Down by Covid-19
summary: In one rural Maine county, residents say gas, groceries and heating bills are dimming their holiday cheer. AROOSTOOK COUNTY, Maine-Melissa Holmes works 60 hours a week, up from 40 before the pandemic, managing the short-staffed One Stop Tulsa gas station and convenience store on a snowy stretch in rural northern Maine.

title: 'André Kertész: Postcards From Paris' Review: Brilliant Views From the City of Light
summary: A stunning show of cartes postales shows how the Hungarian photographer came into his own during his years in Paris.. Chicago

title: Six Exercises to Protect Your Lower Back and Knees
summary: Resume Subscription. We rely on the muscles that run along the backside of the body for stability and power. Yet many popular forms of exercise-like running or walking-mainly strengthen the muscles along our bodies' front side.

title: After Battling Israel, Hamas's Popularity Rests on Hopes It Can Collect the West Bank's Trash
summary: Resume Subscription. AL-MAZRAA, West Bank-A bloody 11-day conflict with Israel in spring gave Hamas a jolt of popular support among Palestinians in the West Bank. Now, local elections this week will provide one of the first tests of whether the militant group's gains are lasting.

title: Uber, Lyft Drivers Want More Protection Amid Rising Crime
summary: Resume Subscription. Lyft driver Lamont Liner thought he was picking up a regular fare in Chicago late last year. Instead, his passengers pulled out a pistol and stole his car and phone. He hasn't returned to drive for the app since, even as ride-sharing companies have tried to tempt drivers with more money.

title: Overdraft Fees Enrich Banks, and the Biden Administration Wants Less of That
summary: U.S. regulators are telling financial institutions to scale back fees for consumers who exceed their account balance. WASHINGTON-Banks are under renewed regulatory pressure to overhaul their overdraft-fee practices, which generate billions of dollars of revenue from consumers who are often cash-strapped.

title: To Canonize a New Catholic Saint, It Takes a Miracle
summary: A drive to name the first Black American saints will need to meet a stringent Vatican standard for verifying divine intercession. Last month at a church in Baltimore, a group of Catholics launched a campaign calling on Pope Francis to name six men and women the first Black Catholic saints from the U.S. The six candidates include Mother Mary Elizabeth Lange (ca. 1789-1882), who founded a school for Black girls in Baltimore in 1828, and the Rev. Augustus Tolton (1854-1897), who was born in slavery and studied for the priesthood in Rome after being rejected from every American seminary to which he had applied.

title: Molson Coors Decided to Reopen Its Offices. Things Got Complicated.
summary: Resume Subscription. Molson Coors Beverage Co. learned some lessons after bringing corporate employees back to their offices in October. Color-coded wristbands can help colleagues signal their openness to a hug. It's important to schedule 10 minutes of travel time between meetings. And it's tough to get some people into meeting rooms with masks if they can join a video call without a mask from their desk.

title: How Airbnb's Seniormost Female Executive Transformed Vulnerability Into Courage
summary: Catherine Powell started at the rental giant just before the pandemic upended travel. She quickly stepped into an even bigger role.. In Personal Board of Directors, top business leaders talk about the people they turn to for advice, and how those people have shaped their perspective and helped them succeed. Previous installments from the series are here.

title: The Challenging Road Ahead for Rivian's Billionaire CEO
summary: RJ Scaringe turned a childhood obsession with cars into one of the year's hottest IPOs. Now he must fend off stiff competition while churning out three new electric-vehicle models at the same time.. RJ Scaringe grew up studying the auto industry, peering under parked cars as a teenager and stashing spare parts around his bedroom. Now, at 38, he wants to disrupt it.
